intro: Gironniera subaequalis var. scabrida, commonly known as the roughleaf gironniera, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its rough, hairy leaves and showy, pink to red bracteate flowers that bloom in summer. It typically grows in moist, wooded areas and is often found in swampy or wetland habitats. This variety is distinguished by its slightly scabrous leaf surface, contributing to its unique botanical appearance.
